abstract:
<jats:p>In a cheap‐talk setting where the conflict of interest between sender and receiver is determined endogenously by the choice of parameters 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic>
            <jats:sub>
              <jats:italic>i</jats:italic>
            </jats:sub> for each agent 
            <jats:italic>i</jats:italic>, conditions are provided that determine the sign of each agent's inverse demand for 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic> without assuming that the most informative equilibrium will necessarily be played in the cheap talk game. For two popular functional forms of payoffs, we derive analytically tractable approximations for agent 
            <jats:italic>i</jats:italic>'s demand for 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic>. In an application where the 
            <jats:italic>θi</jats:italic>'s are purchased on a competitive market, we provide conditions for a competitive equilibrium to feature maximal information transmission. In a principal–agent application where the agent's 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic> is set by the principal, our results show that information transmission will be partial. We consider extensions where: (1) the 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic>'s are acquired covertly rather than overtly and (2) the 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic>'s are traded 
            <jats:italic>after</jats:italic> the sender has received the information.
          </jats:p>
title: Cheap Talk With Endogenous Conflict of Interest
